item.title: Poetics I
item.description:
Some Context #

For Aristotle, the evolution of human culture is in large part the evolution of technê.

We must point out that poetry, here, does not necessarily refer to what we today think of as literature in verse. The word used by Aristotle is ποιητής (pi.i’tis) which translates to ‘work’ or ‘creation’ - this word is used to describe all those products of language from verse to prose to lyric poetry and even treatises of philosophy and science. For Aristotle mimetic works also include music and painting. I agree with Malcom Heath who defends his translation of ‘mimesis’ to mean imitation rather than representation as–he puts it–the term representation fails to capture the subtle meaning behind Aristotle’s use of mimesis; the eagle is a symbol used to represent Zeus, but it is by no means an imitation in the way that the statue on Olympia would have been.
